data.title: Celebrating the incredible talent of Amy Winehouse ❤️
data.meta_description: Celebrating the life, career and music of Amy Winehouse as her biopic film Back To Black is released in cinemas on 12th April 2024.
data.text:
The biopic Back to Black is out now

It's been 13 years since the untimely death of Amy Winehouse, an incredibly talented musician and performer, who is often heralded as having one of the most beautiful singing voices of all time.

Now, as the biopic about the late singer is released, named after her song and album, 'Back To Black', we take a look at her amazing career.

Inspired by Jazz music, Amy enjoyed huge success during her all-too-short career, releasing two studio albums 'Frank' and 'Back to Black', along with chart-topping singles 'Rehab' and 'Valerie', which was a cover of The Zutons' song. She changed the landscape of pop music forever.

Amy sadly died on 23rd July 2011 at the age of 27, leaving a legacy of incredible music and the Amy Winehouse Foundation, which works with young people to improve their confidence and self-esteem.

Back to Black was released on 12th April, and stars Industry actress Marisa Abela as Amy, along with Jack O'Connell, Eddie Marsan, and Lesley Manville. The film follow's Amy's life as she becomes famous, including her performance at Glastonbury in 2008.

Take a look at Amy Winehouse's career:

What are Amy Winehouse's biggest songs?

'Rehab'

'Rehab' was written and recorded by Amy Winehouse and was released in October 2006. Produced by Mark Ronson, the track is autobiographical and tells the story of Amy's refusal to attend an alcohol rehabilitation centre.

The track earned Amy three Grammy Awards and an Ivor Novello Award.

'Valerie'

A cover of The Zutons, 'Valerie' was a collaboration with producer Mark Ronson and is one of Amy Winehouse's most successful releases. It earned Amy a BRIT Award nomination.

'Tears Dry On Their Own'

Taken from Amy's seminal album 'Back to Black', 'Tears Dry On Their Own' was released in August 2007 as the fourth single from the LP.
